text: we start in Beijing where authorities
are racing to contain a corona virus
outbreak linked to Asia's biggest
wholesale market all entertainment in
indoor sports venues are being closed
and 21 housing estates have been locked
down as cases increased the city had
previously seen no signs of the virus
for more than 50 days the outbreak is
focused on sprawling Shin Fadi market
where more than 10,000 people work it
supplies a massive 80 percent of
Beijing's fresh produce including meat
seafood seafood and vegetables which
come from within China and overseas
spanning an area nearly the size of 160
football pitches the market is 20 times
larger than the Wuhan market where it
spread from late last year more cases
have also been reported at a second
market you chew on dong thigh several
kilometers away our China correspondent
Steven McDonald reports residents in
large parts of southwestern Beijing are
again behind fences as it fears that a
second wave of the coronavirus would
take hold housing estates have been
sealed off to all but those who live
there
deliveries must be made to the perimeter
fence only shops schools and some public
transport have been closed I'd be lying
if I said I wasn't worried
I came to Beijing on the 13th if this
was one day later then I definitely
wouldn't be able to come right now there
aren't many people on the subway there
aren't as many as before
in Beijing today dozens of new confirmed
coronavirus infections have been added
to the tally has been growing since the
end of last week it may not sound like
many but it's caused quite some concern
especially to consider from where the
clusters emanated the massive Shin Fadi
wholesale market responsible for 80
percent of the city's vegetables and
meat has been shut for cleaning and
testing all the infections in this
cluster have been traced back to the
market in some way China's officials say
they're hoping to test up to
200-thousand people who've visited Shin
favi in the last two weeks as well as
90,000 residents in the response to
Beijing's cluster we're seeing the best
and worst of China's communist party on
the one hand the speed and the scale of
the social isolation of the testing has
been something to behold
on the other the party is also being
criticized for going after scapegoats
for dismissing local officials on whose
watch the outbreak occurred if you
wanted to guarantee a culture whereby
cover-up was your first choice rather
than open reporting there's probably not
a better way to do it
Stephen MacDonald BBC News Beijing well
I've been speaking to professor Ben
cowling head of Epidemiology at the
university of hong kong i asked him
about the claim that this new outbreak
came from a chopping board
there's virus detected on this
particular chopping board is not clear
how it got there they've also tested a
lot of the meat to fish all those kind
of samples they haven't found the virus
so most likely the virus got on the
chopping board from the person who was
using it and they've actually halted the
import of salmon from from across the
globe and and namely from from Norway is
it even possible that it could somehow
get into any kind of food or meat fish I
mean theory it's possible but it's
really really really unlikely and I
don't think it's the explanation for
this particular outbreak there's a lot
of questions also now being asked about
the sort of testing and tracing and the
of whether that can contain the outbreak
do you think in this case it's worked
well so tracing has found a lot of cases
that would not have otherwise been found
in Beijing but the Chinese health
authorities clearly don't want to rely
on tests and trace because they've
locked down these districts to try and
limit the opportunities to spread so I
suppose the question then is how are you
likely to get the one case yeah we don't
know where it came from but we know
there's always the chance for sporadic
infections to pop up maybe an
asymptomatic case who was infected
elsewhere in China travel to Beijing
didn't even know he had kovat and spread
it into this particular market China has
been whether were given the accurate
information praised for the way it has
handled this this outbreak you know
since the very beginning in whoo-ha and
the way that they've locked things down
they've started to ease the lockdown in
the last few weeks do you think that
that has also played a role in it it's a
good time to lift
lockdowns when the case numbers go down
to zero as they have done in much of
China but I think we then recognize
there's a risk of infections coming back
and a second wave beginning and that's
what it looks like now but if lock downs
are put back in place then it'll be a
very small second wave much smaller than
in many other parts of the world so I
suppose as many European countries start
to open up should they be looking to
China now and and and worrying certainly
I mean it does indicate the risk whether
it's after a week or a month or in this
case after two months after their large
local case infections will come back
sooner or later it doesn't mean that
lock downs are the best thing to do they
are very good for stopping transmission
but they're also very damaging to the
economy so not every country is going to
go down that path again
so could you then help our audience you
know better understand as we sort of
start to ease things what are the best
practices I know we've told our
audiences these from the very beginning
but what are the best things to do to
ensure that I suppose you don't catch it
and and that it is contained I think
South Korea and Japan are really good
models so they do a lot of testing they
find a lot of cases and they do tests
and trace so they find the contacts and
try and stop change
mission they also have everybody
avoiding crowded places wearing masks in
public and those are really important to
limit the opportunities of transmission
to slow things down basically and then
to buy time so neither I mean South
Korea has not had a lockdown at any
point in the last few months and they've
managed to keep the case numbers at a
low level very successfully so that's a
good model that's professor Ben cowling
speaking to me there a little earlier
